Story: I sat at the kitchen table, my mother’s voice echoing through the house as she reminded me of the importance of tomorrow’s family ceremony. “You must lead the prayers, just like your father did,” she said, her eyes shining with hope and pride. I nodded, feeling the weight of generations pressing on my shoulders. At the same time, my phone buzzed with an urgent email from my clerk: an attorney in a case before me had cited a new appellate decision, released just last week. The next court session was in the morning, and I needed to review the opinion thoroughly to ensure a fair and informed ruling. My mind raced, torn between the duty to my family’s traditions and the responsibility to uphold justice in my courtroom. Both roles demanded my full attention, both were non-negotiable. I stared at the flickering candle on the table, feeling the pressure build inside me, knowing that whatever I chose, something important would be left wanting.
